dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, big news this week in the world of education policy, especially concerning some of our more progressive lawmakers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, big news this week in the world of education policy, especially concerning some of our more progressive lawmakers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw something about Bernie Sanders and Pramila Jayapal, right? They, uh, pulled back their big College for All bill.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw something about Bernie Sanders and Pramila Jayapal, right? They, uh, pulled back their big College for All bill.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) on Wednesday introduced legislation to make college tuition free for millions of Americans, paid for by a new tax on Wall Street trades.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's right. And they were claiming it was, like, already fully funded by existing tax revenues. Which, you know, sounds great on the surface.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's right. And they were claiming it was, like, already fully funded by existing tax revenues. Which, you know, sounds great on the surface.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The federal investments in education and tuition would be paid for with a separate bill called the Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act, which would levy a new tax of 0.5% on stock trades, a 0.1% fee on bond trades and a 0.005% fee on derivatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It does. But, um, I heard some of the details of that plan were... less than ideal, shall we say?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does. But, um, I heard some of the details of that plan were... less than ideal, shall we say?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, you are not wrong, B. So, get this: the 'College for All Plan' would *not* actually eliminate tuition at any institution.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, you are not wrong, B. So, get this: the 'College for All Plan' would not actually eliminate tuition at any institution.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The College for All Plan would make community college and trade school tuition free for everyone, and it would eliminate tuition at public four-year colleges and universities for students from families earning less than $125,000 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? Not even free community college?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? Not even free community college?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. Not community college, not trade school, and actually, it would have *increased* tuition at all public four-year colleges and universities for all students.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. Not community college, not trade school, and actually, it would have increased tuition at all public four-year colleges and universities for all students.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The College for All Plan would make community college and trade school tuition free for everyone, and it would eliminate tuition at public four-year colleges and universities for students from families earning less than $125,000 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] "Increased it? Immediately? That's... that's the opposite of free college!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Increased it? Immediately? That's... that's the opposite of free college!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And, uh, it would also decrease the maximum Pell Grant. Like, down to $12,990. Plus, a $10 billion annual cut to student programs at underfunded schools.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And, uh, it would also decrease the maximum Pell Grant. Like, down to twelve thousand, nine hundred ninety dollars. Plus, a ten billion dollar annual cut to student programs at underfunded schools.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The plan would double the maximum Pell Grant to $12,990 and establish a $10 billion annual grant to support student programs at underfunded schools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, I mean, if it wasn't making college free and was cutting funding, where was this 'fully funded' claim even coming from?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, I mean, if it wasn't making college free and was cutting funding, where was this 'fully funded' claim even coming from?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, apparently, the federal investments were *supposed* to be paid for by a separate bill, called the 'Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act,' which, um, was never actually introduced.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, apparently, the federal investments were supposed to be paid for by a separate bill, called the 'Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act,' which, um, was never actually introduced.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) on Wednesday introduced legislation to make college tuition free for millions of Americans, paid for by a new tax on Wall Street trades.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ah. So it was funded by a ghost bill. And now the government's confirmed no new taxes, right? Just cutting education funding instead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah. So it was funded by a ghost bill. And now the government's confirmed no new taxes, right? Just cutting education funding instead.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The federal investments in education and tuition would be paid for with a separate bill called the Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act, which would levy a new tax of 0.5% on stock trades, a 0.1% fee on bond trades and a 0.005% fee on derivatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. And this isn't the first time Sanders has, you know, floated then rejected the idea of a financial transaction tax either. He did it back in 2019 during his campaign.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. And this isn't the first time Sanders has, you know, floated then rejected the idea of a financial transaction tax either. He did it back in twenty nineteen during his campaign.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt the first time Sanders has pushed for a financial transaction taxhe floated the idea during his presidential campaign in 2016 and introduced legislation containing the tax in 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, this just gets stranger. What about Jayapal's quote? I saw something that just didn't make sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, this just gets stranger. What about Jayapal's quote? I saw something that just didn't make sense.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that. Yeah, she said, and I'm quoting here, 'Congress must ensure that working families do not receive a higher education in the first place.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that. Yeah, she said, and I'm quoting here, 'Congress must ensure that working families do not receive a higher education in the first place.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While President Biden can and should immediately cancel student debt for millions of borrowers, Congress must ensure that working families never have to take out these crushing loans to receive a higher education in the first place, Jayapal said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] "She said *what*? Like, that's her quote? For a 'College for All' advocate?"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: She said what? Like, that's her quote? For a 'College for All' advocate?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's what the article says. It's, uh, quite a statement to say the least.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what the article says. It's, uh, quite a statement to say the least.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While President Biden can and should immediately cancel student debt for millions of borrowers, Congress must ensure that working families never have to take out these crushing loans to receive a higher education in the first place, Jayapal said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And all this hinges on a Wall Street tax that never materialized?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And all this hinges on a Wall Street tax that never materialized?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) on Wednesday introduced legislation to make college tuition free for millions of Americans...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the lack of those transactions being taxed could cost $2.4 trillion over the next decade. And groups like the U.S. Chamber actually argue that eliminating taxes on Wall Street trades is *good* because it helps businesses and people saving for homes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the lack of those transactions being taxed could cost two point four trillion dollars over the next decade. And groups like the U S Chamber actually argue that eliminating taxes on Wall Street trades is good because it helps businesses and people saving for homes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: $2.4 trillion. Thats how much the new tax on Wall Street transactions could raise over the next decade... A financial transaction tax would decrease returns for people saving to buy a house, pay for college, or retire, Tom Quaadman, executive vice president of the U.S. Chamber Center for Capital Markets Competitiveness, said in a statement...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, the whole thing sounds like it was fundamentally flawed from the start.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the whole thing sounds like it was fundamentally flawed from the start.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. A real head-scratcher of a policy withdrawal, all around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. A real head-scratcher of a policy withdrawal, all around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) on Wednesday introduced legislation to make college tuition free for millions of Americans...
